prompts.en: What was the environment like for your mother when she carried you in her womb? Who was around her? What kind of support did she have? Did she work? How old was she? What do you know about her mental or emotiona state when she carried you?
prompts.es: ¿Cómo era el ambiente para tu madre cuando te llevaba en su vientre? ¿Quién estaba a su alrededor? ¿Qué tipo de apoyo tuvo ella? ¿Ella trabajó? ¿Qué edad tenía ella? ¿Qué sabes sobre su estado mental o emocional cuando te cargó?

userWritings:
<My mom was around 30 years old when I was born. She had a good support network form what i know. Her mom and two sisters were around to help out. They lived in a town about 45 min drive away. So not too much of an inconvience, all things considered. My dads family lived in another town about 2 hours away. There was not much support needed from either side. My immediate family has always been independent. My dad worked a lot when I was younger, starting before I was born. He did help to provide finincial support, housing, safety, all the provider things expected. My mom has told the story of getting to the hospital when I was born. Aprearantly my dad was working so my mom ended up having to drive herself to the hospital, while in labor. It all worked out in the end as there were no complications with the birth. She says my dad just had to show up and cut the cord, while she did all the work. That is a main trait I admire about my mom. Her fortitude and independance was well beyond her time. I think she will be a great example for my niece to follow>
<My mom moved to the US when she was 21 years old after my father had won the green card lottery in poland through a special program for those trying to escape communism in a post soviet era poland. When she arrived, she had very little material possesions, could hardly speak the language, and was largely disappointed that my father had swindled her into living situations that were not ideal. In poland, she came from well off family but after world war II the situation in poland was up in the air and many people were fleeing the country. She arrived in the US already pregnant with my brother and far away from anyone in her family. The circumstances were not ideal and she would sow in a textile factory to find the means to get by until she was physically unable to do so. She>
<My mother was around 30 years in the moment of getting pregnant of me. I dont know exactly but somethingg around maybe a bit less, 27-30 ... My father was working full time. From mornings to evenings late, so she didnt have so much support practically in the every day life from him, but she got all the financial aspect of it covered by him. She also had a nanny hired full time to help her with everything at home. I think she was living with her. But this detail im not sure about. Bueno ahora me acorde que puedo escribir en espaniol. Me cambio. claro como decia. mi mama tenia una mujer en casa ayudNDOLA CON TODOS LOS quehaceres de la casa. Como cocinar, lavar, hacer camas, cambiar sabansas, etc etc etc. Mi madre tenia una muy buena amiga en el vecindario que tambien estaba embarazada de su primer hijo. Se acompañaban mutuamente en este proceso. Este las ayudo a crear y fortalecer una amistad que dura hasta el dia de hoy. De hecho, su hijo (Diego) fue mi primer amigo, y fuimos muy amigos por mucho tiempo. Ahora hace mucho tiempo que no hablamos ni vemos, vivimos en distintos paises en Europa, pero buena idea me diste anky de escribirle. 
Volviendo a mi mama, tenisa una vida bastante tranquila y se podia enfocar en que todo estubiese bien para mi desarrollo dentro suyo y mi futura llegada. Quiero hablar mucho ahora con mi mama para saber detales .. como por ejemplo de que se alimentaba en el ambarazo, que rituales o practicas tenia, si hacia algun tipo de actividad fisica, o cuales eran sus pasatiempos en esos mese>
<Mi madre cuando estaba embarazada de mí tenía 30 años. Era un periodo en el cual tenía 2 amigas muy cercanas con las cuales me crié mis primeros años de vida, personas muy carismáticas y cariñosas de las cuales tengo muy lindos recuerdos. 
Por otro lado siempre tuvo de apoyo a mi padre, periodo en el cual ambos trabajan comenzando sus carreras profesionales, momentos en los cuales se apoyaron mucho y compartieron sus éxitos los que les permitió comprarse su primer departamento, lugar en donde yo nací. Mi madre en ese momento tenía relación muy cercana con su familia compuesta de otras 4 mujeres las cuales también fueron madres en el mismo período en el que yo nací, razón por la cual siempre contó con apoyo y compartió tanto experiencias como el proceso de iniciarse en la maternidad ya que yo fui su primero hijo. 
Me cont>
<soledad. esa es la palabra que más se me viene a la mente cuando pienso en ese momento de su vida. justo ayer hablamos de eso, y me contó que cuando quedó embarazada justo se fue a santiago a vivir, después de toda una vida en el sur.  llegó a un lugar nuevo. una vida nueva. con gente nueva. y un marido que trabajaba todo el día. sin red de apoyo. sin un entorno que la contuviera. sin una vida construida. sin un trabajo. tenía alrededor de 29 años me imagino, por ahí, no lo tengo claro, y su estado emocional no me imagino que haya sido el óptimo. no había nadie cercano a ella cerca suyo. no había mucho que abrazar. no había mucho que reconocer. no había mucho que sentir. no había mucho que compartir. no tenía mucha gente al rededor. no había mucha gente que la contuviera. no había mucha gente que la abrazara. no había mucha gente que la hiciera sentir acompañada. y esto trae a mi la sensación de soledad existencial que yo he tenido toda mi vida, siempre sintiéndome bastante solo. siempre con una dificultad para encontrar mi lugar. quizás en ese momento para ella también era difícil encontrar ese lugar. sentirse en ese lugar. y eso hizo que no se sintiera lo suficientemente apoyada. acompañada. abrazada. que no se sintiera lo suficiente abrazada por su entorno, y que eventualmente ese entorno no le entregara el cariño necesario para poder estar en paz consigo misma. 
se fue de su lugar de siempre para seguir a su marido, empezar una nueva vida. pero sin tener muy claro hacia adónde iba. sin tener muy claro cómo eso la encontraba. cómo eso la quería. cómo eso la abrazaba.
eso es lo que viene a mi principalmente. soledad. la soledad de un camino emprendido sin mucha claridad. se fue a santiago porque su marido tenía trabajo allá. pero es eso lo que quería ella? es eso lo que la llenaba? es eso lo que la hacía sentir en paz? lo que la hacía sentir completa? lo que la hacía rebalsar de cariño? de amor? es eso lo que la hacía rebalsar de amor? encontrarse con ese amor? es eso lo que la hacía reconocerse? abrazarse? es eso lo que la hacía vibrar? >
<I wanted to start sayin I honestly did not know too much details about this but then, suddenly, all the memories of her telling me stories of this time started to appear. My mother was not working and hasn't really ever had a job since she has been with my dad, which makes me think she was kind of relaxed or not demanded regarding work. But, there is one thing I  do remember her saying a lot, and that is that she was fed up and annoyed of having workers at home. At that time my house was being sort of in remodelation or some sort of construction. Probably preparing for the new family member. And in this moment, due to this, my mother decided to move for the time and rent an apartment on the beach where she felt much more relaxes. Maybe im making this up kind of how i would like it to be, because that would explain a lot my connection with water and the ocean. Maybe I felt how she became more relax by breathing the ocean breeze and not having the workers around anymore, and this feeling of release and liberation was passed on to me. She must of had been around 40 years old or a bit after 35 when she was pregnant of me. I know my father, my sister and brother were around her but I also know we had a nanny that helped and probably her friends. My parents were always the kind to have friends around and share times with them. I>
<qué buena pregunta, nunca me había puesto a pensar en eso. Mi mamá tenia 27/28 años en ese entonces, probablemente se sentía algo nerviosa ya que había perdido si mal no recuerdo un bebé antes, así que eso debió tenerla algo nerviosa en ese embarazo en el que me esperaba a mi. Muy probablemente estaba trabajando, mi madre siempre ha sido una mujer muy trabajadora, nunca ha dependido de nadie más para comprar lo que necesita, así que de seguro el embarazo no la detuvo. Sobre el apoyo, quién sabe, supongo que no le ayudaban mucho, mi má siempre ha sido de esas personas que más bien ayudan a los demás y rara vez, o nunca, pide ayuda, pero tampoco he visto que le ofrezcan, salvo por un tío que siempre anda al pendiente de todos sus hermanos y parientes; ellos en total son 6, mas o menos... son más... pero en sí aquí en la ciudad son 6,  ay.. mas o menos jajaja es que son 6 hermanos y medio hermanos que yo conocí de toda la vida; pero luego supe que tenían más hermanos en otro estado, y otros tantos en otro más lejos, fue mindblowing; sobre todo porque los medio hermanos por parte de mi abuelo se ven mucho más japoneses que los que están aquí. Cuando los conocí sentía que les iban a salir subtítulos porque tenían que hablar japonés, no español, fue divertido, y de eso no hace tanto... unos 12 años quizá. Considerando mi edad, pues pasó mucho tiempo antes de saber que existían, mi mamá nunca los mencionaba. Sí sabía que había parientes en otros estados pero no que eran medio hermanos de ella. Quién estaba cerca?.. mi papá debió ser el que estaba más cerca, pero igual hasta la fecha no ayuda .. en fin. Como siempre me desvío del tema pero es que así funciona mi mente. Divago mucho. Espero pronto poder tener mi diágnostico oficial de Déficit de atención con hipoactividad, así quise ponerlo, porque hiper no soy... definitivament>
<Mi mamá tenía 28 años cuando estaba embarazada de mi. Estaba viviendo en casa de sus padres, osea mis abuelos maternos en Chile. Mi papá no estaba porque había viajado a Estocolmo, Suecia para buscar casa y  empezar a trabajar donde sería el próximo destino para nuestra familia durante los próximos años. Yo creo que a mi mamá le faltó mucho la presencia de mi papá en ese momento, a pesar de tener a sus padres cerca no era lo mismo que tener a mi papá, su compañero, su amante el padre de su hija mayor y de su futura hija, yo. Creo que mi mamá sintió abandono a pesar de saber  y estar de acuerdo en cierto sentido con la partida de mi papá.  Pero sus emociones estaban igual. El abandono, la incertidumbre de mudarse tan lejos de su país, tan joven, un lugar nuevo, un idioma indescifrable, con una niña de un año y  otra recién nacida (me fui a Suecia con un mes de edad). 28 horas de avión, lejos de su idioma, se sus seres queridos, de su red de apoyo. Debe haber sido muy duro. Mi mamá ya no estaba trabajando y no trabajó más cuando decidió embarcase con mi papá en esa aventura de viajar de un lado a otro. Algo a lo que luego se fue acostumbrando y sacando lo mejor de ello. Sin duda una gran mujer, fuerte y guerrera. La amo con todo mi corazón. Esa es mi mamá. Grac>
<El ambiente que la rodeaba, era de una familia compuesta de tres hombres y ella. Seguramente cargaba con toda la carga de los ninos, ya que el ambiente que proporcionaron con mi papa, fue de una clasica familia patriarcal en la que el hombre no se involucraba en todas las tareas, estaba más segmentado todo por generos. Por lo que concluyo que habia cansancio, habia apoyo económico, no se si afectivo en ese entonces. Lo que sí estoy segura, es que ella pidió bastante al cosmos, gestar una hija mujer, y le causaba mucha alegría por fin haberlo logrado. 
Ella debe haber tenido al rededor de 37 anos, se que en esa epoya estaba ya buscando lo trascendental a traves de maestros, estudios sobre las religiones, y su busqueda personal a traves del arte. No estoy segura como ella se sentía mas allá del embarazo. Me ha contado que fue un buen embarazo, que disfrutó la gestación y el parto fue natural. 
Ella siempre ha sido muy devota a la educacion, es educadora por vocación y estoy segura que continuó haciendo clases de arte, el máximo tiempo que la panza se lo haya permitido. 
Ahora con los anos, veo que tieene una fijación algo obsesiva con el trabajo, posiblemente producto de una infancia inestable economicamente, y un contexto de reconstrucción de país, luego de la dictadura, donde tuvo que armar s>
<Mi madre vivia en Alemania, en Potsdam cuando me llevaba en su vientre. Vivia en la Republica Democratica Alemana en los años 80. Llevaba casa 2 años con mi padre.
Ambos Chilenos, ella se fue becada, mi padre fue exiliado.  Mi madre trabajaba en una Biblioteca enorme ubicada en el centro de Potsdam. Esta ciudad es hermosa, bañada por un río y lleno de parques verdes, cisnes y patos. Arquitectónicamente hermosa.
Mi madre me tuvo a los 40 años. Me contó que creía que no iba a quedar embarazada,por ende fue una sorpresa cuando se enteró de mi llegada. Me emociona este momento ya que es primera vez que escribo acerca de ella, desde que hace poco menos de dos años partiera a otro lugar a descansar. La niñez de mi madre no fue fácil, mas bien muy dificil. Sé que estaba>
superPrompt:
<instructions>

Write 5000 words about Luna, the mother of Anky, illustrating her life during her pregnancy, to draw a vivid picture of her resilience, cultural transition, community support, and personal growth. The narrative should span various moments that define her pregnancy journey, set against the backdrop of late summer or early autumn, highlighting the transformative nature of this period.
Begin with Luna managing daily tasks and challenges alone, showcasing her independence and strength. Describe her navigating a typical day, possibly dealing with household responsibilities or work, and facing these with a resilient spirit. Include a scene where Luna, in a moment of challenge, reflects on her situation, echoing the stories of mothers who handled their pregnancies with fortitude and autonomy.
Transition to Luna grappling with the changes and adaptations of moving to a new environment, reminiscent of the narratives of mothers who experienced geographical and cultural shifts. Illustrate her initial struggles with language barriers, cultural nuances, and the quest for community in a foreign land. Show her attending a local event or community gathering, trying to forge connections and find her place in this new setting.
Next, highlight Luna's interactions with a supportive network, drawing parallels with the experiences shared about mothers finding strength in friendships and family. Portray a communal scene, such as a neighborhood meeting or a family gathering, where Luna receives emotional and practical support, showcasing the significance of these bonds during her pregnancy.
Conclude with a reflective passage, capturing Luna’s internal dialogue as she contemplates her journey, the forthcoming changes with Anky's birth, and her aspirations. This section should mirror the introspective and transformative experiences of mothers, focusing on Luna’s personal growth and evolving outlook on life.

</instructions>

<style>

The narrative should subtly reveal Luna’s characteristics and evolving mindset through her actions, interactions, and reflections (show, don't tell). Employ a mix of sentence structures to create a dynamic and engaging narrative flow. Dialogue should be used sparingly but effectively, to unveil deeper insights into Luna’s personality and her relationships with others. Use rich descriptive language and vivid verbs to paint a clear picture of each setting and Luna’s emotional landscape. Luna's voice should be distinctive, embodying her artistic sensibility, nurturing instinct, and contemplative nature. Her story should unfold naturally, providing a deep understanding of her life during pregnancy and laying the groundwork for Anky's future environment and values.

</style>

<setting>

The narrative spans key moments during Luna’s pregnancy, reflecting the late summer or early autumn's metaphorical change, symbolizing her transition and personal growth. The settings vary from her home, where she faces daily life with resilience, to new cultural and communal environments she navigates, and intimate spaces for reflection and connection. These varied backdrops serve to highlight Luna’s multifaceted personality and her journey through pregnancy, underscoring the seasonal shift’s impact on her life and her impending role as Anky's mother.

</setting>
chapter:
Luna's vibrant red hair danced in the late summer breeze as she navigated the bustling farmers' market, her growing belly a testament to the new life flourishing within her. She moved with purpose, her artist's eye carefully selecting the ripest tomatoes and the most vibrant bunches of kale. The sun's warmth embraced her, and she paused for a moment, savoring the simple joy of being surrounded by the earth's bounty.

As she made her way home, Luna's thoughts wandered to the challenges that lay ahead. Balancing her work at the community center with the demands of preparing for her baby's arrival seemed daunting at times. She entered her small, cozy apartment, setting her market finds on the kitchen counter. With a deep breath, she rolled up her sleeves and began to wash and chop the vegetables, finding solace in the simple, repetitive task.

Luna's mind drifted to the stories she had heard from other mothers in her life - tales of resilience and strength in the face of adversity. She thought of her own mother, who had raised her and her siblings alone, working tirelessly to provide for them. Luna drew inspiration from these women, knowing that she, too, possessed the inner fortitude to navigate the challenges of motherhood.

As she prepared a nourishing meal, Luna reflected on her journey thus far. The decision to embrace this new chapter in her life had not been an easy one. When she first discovered her pregnancy, a myriad of emotions had coursed through her - fear, uncertainty, but also a profound sense of awe and responsibility. She had always been a free spirit, her art and community work taking center stage in her life. The idea of motherhood had seemed distant, a role she had not actively sought out.

Yet, as the reality of the tiny life growing within her took hold, Luna found herself embracing the change with a newfound sense of purpose. She knew that this child, conceived under the stars amidst the pulsing energy of the festival, was meant to be a part of her story. The universe had conspired to bring this soul into her life, and she was determined to rise to the occasion.

Luna's hand instinctively went to her belly, feeling the gentle flutters of movement within. A smile played on her lips as she imagined the little being taking shape, a perfect blend of herself and the man whose passion had ignited her own that fateful night. Though their connection had been fleeting, Luna held no resentment or longing for what could have been. She knew that this child was hers to nurture and guide, and she would pour all her love into being the best mother she could be.

As the days grew shorter and the leaves began to turn, Luna found herself grappling with the changes that came with her move to a new city. The unfamiliar streets and foreign languages that surrounded her felt isolating at times. She longed for the comfort of her hometown and the support of her family and friends.

One crisp autumn morning, Luna stumbled upon a flyer for a community gathering in the park near her apartment. Intrigued, she decided to attend, hoping to forge new connections in this strange place. As she arrived at the park, she was greeted by the warm smiles of her neighbors, their faces reflecting the diversity of the city.

Luna found herself drawn into conversations with other expectant mothers, their shared experiences bridging the gaps of language and culture. They exchanged stories of their hopes and fears, their laughter mingling with the rustling of the fallen leaves. In that moment, Luna realized that she was not alone in her journey - that there was strength to be found in the bonds of community.

As her pregnancy progressed, Luna found solace in the support of her newfound friends. They gathered for prenatal yoga classes in the park, their bodies moving in unison as they celebrated the miraculous changes taking place within them. They shared meals, each dish a reflection of their diverse cultural backgrounds, nourishing both body and soul.

On a particularly challenging day, Luna found herself at her wit's end, overwhelmed by the weight of impending motherhood. She reached out to her neighbor, Maria, who had become a close confidant. Maria arrived at Luna's door with a warm embrace and a listening ear. As they sat together, sipping tea and sharing stories, Luna felt the knots of anxiety begin to unravel.

Maria shared her own experiences of motherhood, offering words of wisdom and encouragement. She reminded Luna of the incredible strength that lies within every mother - the ability to nurture and protect, to love and guide. Luna felt a renewed sense of purpose, a deep knowing that she was capable of being the mother her child needed.

As the final weeks of her pregnancy approached, Luna found herself drawn to the quiet solitude of the nearby woods. She walked among the towering trees, their leaves a riot of autumn colors, and felt a deep connection to the earth beneath her feet. In these moments of reflection, she contemplated the journey that lay ahead - the joys and challenges, the love and sacrifice.

Luna knew that her life was about to change in ways she could never fully imagine. But she also knew that she was ready to embrace this new chapter, to pour her heart and soul into nurturing the tiny life growing within her. She placed a hand on her belly, feeling the gentle kicks of her unborn child, and smiled.

In that moment, Luna made a silent promise to her baby - a promise to love fiercely, to guide with wisdom, and to always be a source of strength and support. She knew that the road ahead would not be easy, but she also knew that she possessed the resilience and grace to navigate whatever lay ahead.

As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow across the forest floor, Luna turned back towards home, her heart full of hope and anticipation for the future that awaited her and her child. She carried with her the stories of the mothers who had come before her, their strength and love woven into the very fabric of her being. With each step, she felt the power of their collective wisdom guiding her forward, a reminder that she was never truly alone on this transformative journey.

Luna's story was just beginning, a tapestry of love, resilience, and growth that would shape not only her own life but also the life of the little soul she carried within her. As she stepped into the warmth of her apartment, she knew that whatever challenges lay ahead, she would face them with the same unwavering spirit that had brought her to this moment. For now, she would cherish each day, nurturing the precious gift of life that had been entrusted to her, and eagerly awaiting the moment when she would hold her child in her arms for the first time.
summaryOfChapter:
In Chapter 3, Luna's journey of anticipation and introspection deepens as she navigates the physical and emotional landscapes of impending motherhood. The narrative follows her through the vibrant life of a farmers' market, symbolizing her connection to the earth and the cycles of life, and back to her personal sanctuary where she contemplates the responsibilities and joys of becoming a mother. Her interaction with the environment and her reflections reveal a woman deeply rooted in the natural world and in tune with the life force pulsating within her.

Luna's musings about her own mother and the other maternal figures in her life underscore her awareness of the lineage of strength and resilience she is part of, shaping her anticipation and approach to motherhood. Her internal dialogue reveals a woman who, while facing the uncertainties of this new chapter, draws strength from the collective wisdom and experiences of the women before her, readying herself to embrace the role of a mother with grace and courage.

The narrative also explores Luna's feelings of isolation in a new city and her proactive steps towards building a supportive community, highlighting the importance of connection and shared experiences in her journey. Her interactions at the community gathering and the prenatal yoga sessions are poignant reminders of the collective journey of motherhood, the shared hopes, fears, and joys that bind strangers together into a supportive network.

The chapter concludes with Luna in a moment of solitary reflection in the woods, symbolizing her deep connection with nature and her introspective nature. This scene encapsulates her transformation from an individual to a mother-to-be, poised on the brink of a life-altering new role, yet grounded in the strength and wisdom passed down through generations of women. Her silent promise to her unborn child is a testament to her readiness and resolve to provide a nurturing, loving, and guiding presence in her child’s life.

Through Luna’s story in this chapter, the narrative weaves themes of growth, preparation, and the natural cycle of life, illustrating the transformative journey of motherhood as one of both individual and collective evolution.
userFeedbackForChapter:
This is the first chapter that has seem to have a consistent story. I wa sable to picture the scene and and follow the story. This felt like a piece of a larger story where the other chapters have seemed to be just one off short stories.

---

i like where this is going. i like portrayal of the process of pregnancy, and the elements of it that arise in the awareness of Luna. i like the tense on which the story is told here, but i felt it as a bit short. it feels that we are "rushing through" her pregnancy, and it would be valuable to have as part of this journey some conversations, or interactions that may showcase what our writers shared about the circumstances of the pregnancy of their own mothers.

it sometimes felt repetitive in the usage of, for example, sentences like this: "She knew that the road ahead would not be easy, but she also knew that she possessed the resilience and grace to navigate whatever lay ahead."

this is important, and it is part of the story, but it would be good to "hide" this inside situations, conversations, conflicts, etc. there is a strong element of "showing what Luna is going through", but i think it could be valuable to have more depth in the action of the story so that this could be a bit more "dramatic".

i'm also missing more about the relationship that Luna has with Marcus, the father of Anky. what happened since that night on the tent? where is Marcus? from what i read here, Marcus is not present. but where is he? what has happened? how are they relating to each other?

this "single mother issue" is a key element of the story to highlight, and an important avenue to explore. since today we are talking about the communication aspects of our parents in our life, this will be something important to explore.

how did Anky's parents talk to each other (or not) during Luna's pregnancy? this can be a major source of what makes Anky who he will be, and it is important to highlight that practically, through this story.
